data.title: handle unchecked exceptions in handleHttpResponse()
data.body:
#### Issue details

If you look at this file:

https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/net/NetJavaImpl.java

On line 204 handleHttpResponse() of the given listener is called. When I override this method in my HttpResponseListener and within this method an exception is thrown some strange happens:
#### Reproduction steps/code

I made an example project:
https://github.com/TomGrill/NetJavaImplProblemExample

Whenever an exception is thrown within handleHttpResponse() and I do not catch this exception, then the exception will be caught on line 210 and on line 213 the failed() method of my listener is called AFTER handleHttpResponse() has already been called.

So my question is:

Am I supposed to handle unchecked exceptions (for checked exceptions I am of course) within handleHttpResponse() to prevent failed() beeing called? If so I think this is a design flaw since it is very easy to oversee an unchecked exception. Maybe at least put this to the description of the handleHttpResponse() method to warn users about this problem.

It took me quite a while to figure out a bug I had in my code.

Is this good and supposed to be like it is or do we need to rewrite the class above? I am happily making a PR. Just want to discuss what you think before acting.

data.title: BitmapFont not working with small scale on libgdx 1.7.2+
data.body:
I have OrthographicCamera with viewport 16x9. Lets say for example that devices real resolution is 1024x576

``` java
this.cam = new OrthographicCamera(16, 9);
```

I create BitmapFont like this:

``` java
FreetypeFontLoader.FreeTypeFontLoaderParameter params = new FreetypeFontLoader.FreeTypeFontLoaderParameter();
params.fontFileName = "font.ttf";
params.fontParameters.size = 19;
```

Font size in pixels iz 19. That is calculated like this: `screenHeight(576)/cameraViewportHeight(9)*0.3`
0.3 is how big font should be in camera units

Since font is rendered on camera mentioned above, we have to scale font to our camera size:

``` java
font.getData().setScale(0.015f);// 0.3/19
```

I dont know if my math is ok, but this works fine on libgdx version 1.7.1. If i update to any higher version (currently 1.9.2, but i also tried 1.7.2), font just dont display

data.title: Update Net.java
data.body:
Currently, the HTTPResponse implementation returns a Map<String,List<String>> of Headers.
However, HTTPRequests implements Headers as Map<String, String>

That way, it's impossible to addHeader to have multiple headers of the same name (like multiple Cookies).
Changed headers to Map<String, List<String>>
Changed getHeaders accordingly (for request)
Changed setHeader accordingly.
Added addHeader.

data.title: Suggestion: Update from LibGDX 1.7.2 to latest stable or 1.7.3-SNAPSHOT

https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/wiki/Controllers

Thanks.

data.title: Sort GWT tests, remove "optimization" in ScreenUtils
data.body:
Turns out that javascript engines are jiting as much as java vms, which means that micro benchmarks are pretty useless. (E.g. the speed is dependent on which function is called first) :(
Since there is no benchmarking tool for javascript that is as good as [JHM](http://openjdk.java.net/projects/code-tools/jmh/) is for java, I removed the "optimizations".

data.title: com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Camera.unproject alters given Vector3 values
data.body:
Please ensure you have given all the following requested information in your report.
#### Issue details

Method public Vector3 unproject(Vector3 screenCoords) in com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Camera alters values of it's parameter. This is quite surprising given the definition and description in API "Function to translate a point given in screen coordinates to world space."

I would suggest changing the API documentation to be more clear that the contents of the given Vector3 will be also modified.
#### Reproduction steps/code

camera.unproject(tp.set(screenX, screenY, 0))

yields the same result as

Vector3 new_coord = camera.unproject(new Vector3(screenX, screenY,0));
tp.set(new_coord);

If a LibGDX project is opened on the PC (Windows 10, HD Graphics 3000, latest drivers) and JAVA JRE 8 32-bit is installed, the following error is thrown:

"OpenGL 2.0 or higher with the FBO extension is required. OpenGL version 1.1.0"

If JAVA JRE 8 32-bit is uninstalled, and JAVA JRE 7 32-bit is installed instead -- the project runs with no problems.
